To.Name: Madonna, the Infant Christ, and Saint Anne

Relationships.Reason: Leonardo executed 'the Madonna, the Infant Christ, and Saint Anne'
Florentines under Cardinal Ludovico Mezzarota Scarampo fighting against Milanese under Niccolò Piccinino on June 29, 1440
The landscape background, against which Mona Lisa is posed, recalls the severe, rather than exuberant, landscape and the dim vistas of mountain ranges seen in the neighbourhood of his own birthplace.

Leonardo was one of the members of the Committee of Artists summoned to advise the Signoria as to the most suitable site for the erection of Michelangelo's statue of 'David,' which had recently been completed.
In the following May he was commissioned by the Signoria to decorate one of the walls of the Council Hall of the Palazzo Vecchio.
Although he completed the cartoon, the only part of the composition which he eventually executed in colour was an incident in the foreground which dealt with the 'Battle of the Standard.'
It depicts the Florentines under Cardinal Ludovico Mezzarota Scarampo fighting against the Milanese under Niccolò Piccinino.
Leonardo was back in Milan in May 1506 in the service of the French King.
